column1: Public health insurance for unauthorized immigrant adults

column20: State did not have the policy

column1: Source: Julia Gelatt, Hamutal Bernstein, and Heather Koball, "State Immigration Policy Resource," Washington, DC: Urban Institute, May 2017, http://urban.org/features/state-immigration-policy-resource.

Original data sources: "Medical Assistance Programs for Immigrants in Various States," National Immigration Law Center, Issues: Health Care, 2002, 2005–07, 2009–12, 2014–16, Internet Archive: Wayback Machine, https://archive.org/web/.

Karen Tumlin, Wendy Zimmermann, and Jason Ost, "State Snapshots of Public Benefits for Immigrants: A Supplemental Report to 'Patchwork Policies'" (Washington, DC: Urban Institute, 1999), http://www.urban.org/sites/default/files/alfresco/publication-pdfs/309107-State-Snapshots-of-Public-Benefits-for-Immigrants.PDF.
Notes: This table indicates whether each state funds public health insurance for adults who are ineligible for public health insurance due to their immigration status.

Much of this information came from the National Immigration Law Center, which collected information as it came to them and did not always conduct a “50 state check” when they updated the tables. Sometimes their revisions represent a correction rather than a new program or the elimination of a program.
